<发布>;2023-08-29T16:11:19Z</发布>; <更新>;2023-09-04T04:57:01Z</更新>; <摘要类型="html">; <p>;<strong>;注意：</strong>;“纤维”指的是单独的钩和/或环。</p>; <hr />; <p>;想象两片完美的石墨烯片，一片的一面附着有原子直径的碳氢化合物环，另一片的一面附着有原子直径的碳氢化合物钩（链） 。我们将两张纸推在一起，它们相互粘在一起，然后我们将它们拉开。然后我们重复这个过程，但这一次它们更容易分开。在执行此操作 <span class="math-container">;$n^\text{th}$</span>; 时间后，纸张完全停止粘附。我们将这些床单放在神奇的显微镜下看看出了什么问题，结果发现我们小心翼翼地附着在床单上的所有纤维都扭曲和断裂，变成了甲烷、CO<sub>;2</sub>; 和铁丝网。 </p>; <p>;这是因为当放置得足够近时，纤维会相互作用（彼此之间以及与空气之间），形成新的化学键，当我们将薄片拉开时，这些化学键也可能会断裂，从而留下更稳定的结构。我们这样做的次数越多，我们的纤维就越混乱，直到它们完全不再是钩子和环，而是稳定在系统可以采取的最稳定的配置中（我不是化学家，但我绝对确定“分子尼龙搭扣”不是该系统的基态）。</p>; <p>;显然，我们无法制造原子尼龙搭扣 (TM)...</p>; <p>;或者也许我们可以？< /p>; <p>;如果您在显微镜下观察丝状藻，您可能会注意到它有时会缠结成微小的意大利面条球。同样，细菌鞭毛<em>;可能</em>;会缠结在一起（这种情况是否真的发生是一个持续争论的问题），因此纤维<em>;可能</em>;至少小至 10纳米跨度。即使存在如上所述的交互，也许一切都保持“足够经典”。在原子尺度上仍然算作尼龙搭扣吗？可能不是，但我实际上不知道！</p>; <p>;<strong>;多小</strong>; <em>;<strong>;可以</strong>;</em>; <strong>;我们制作魔术贴</ strong>;？</p>; <p>;我们如何得出最佳猜测？有几件事需要考虑：</p>; <ul>; <li>;<p>;<strong>;机械力与分子间力/化学相互作用：</strong>;在某些时候，分子间力超过机械力。也就是说，超出纤维直径的某个下限，组成分子之间的力对于系统的整体行为变得比作用在纤维上的机械力（例如摩擦力、张力等）更重要。</p >; </li>; <li>;<p>;<strong>;经典效应与量子效应：</strong>;在某些时候，量子效应会超越经典效应，我们需要考虑纤维的非经典行为。特别是，足够小的钩子很容易穿过足够小的环，“因为量子”。</p>; </li>; <li>;<p>;<strong>;统计行为：</strong>;虽然纤维几乎当然，有时会变形超过其弹性极限，这种情况在宏观维可牢尼龙搭扣中很少发生，因此粘附力可以可靠地维持一段时间，该时间大于或等于材料通过其他方式（即化学、生物、狗）降解所需的时间。无论你清洗多少次，头发都会粘在你的夹克上）。为了制造微型尼龙搭扣，所有纤维降解所需的时间不应超过每对钩环中至少一根纤维发生机械故障所需的时间。</p>; </li>; </ul>; <p>;（此外，在某些时候，与纤维所附着的表面之间的力相比，纤维之间的相互作用可能变得微不足道）</p>; <hr />; <p>;<strong>;注意：</strong>;因为这个问题涉及经典力学和量子力学（以及统计力学……和连续介质力学）的边界，我不确定如何最好地标记它。如果有人有更合适的标签，请随时编辑！</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <summary type="html">; <p>;For people who don't know what Sodastream is: SodaStream is a system where you can make your own soda at home using regular water and a CO2 cartridge. You put water in the special Sodastream bottle, connect it to the <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; cartridge and pressurize to the target pressure. CO2 gets into the water and soda happens !</p>; <p>;The SodaStream bottle has fill marker which still leaves a fair bit of empty volume. That seems to waste <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; to me, since all this volume has to be compressed by the incoming <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; to create the target pressure. So I have been overfilling my bottles before pressurizing and I was wondering how to run the numbers on that.</p>; <p>;Assumptions:</p>; <ol>; <li>;Total bottle volume: 1010ml</li>; <li>;Official target volume: 828ml</li>; <li>;Overfilled volume: 972ml</li>; <li>;Target pressure: 380 kPa (ambient = 100 kPa)</li>; </ol>; <p>;I can eyeball the amount of <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; needed to build up the pressure from the difference in pressure and the required increase in mass inside the bottle</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$V_{official} = (1010ml - 828ml)\cdot \frac{380kPa}{100kPa} = 691 ml$$</span>;</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$V_{overfill} = (1010ml - 972ml)\cdot \frac{380kPa}{100kPa} = 144 ml $$</span>;</p>; <p>;So that's a substantial savings. However, I can't figure out how to calculate how much <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; actually gets into the water and if the overfilling makes a meaningful difference here.</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/q/776838</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com">;2</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Chemical Potential and Gibbs Energy</stitle>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="thermodynamics">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="energy">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-chemistry">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Zachary Candelaria</name>; <uri>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/users/269702</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/776838/chemical-potential-and-gibbs-energy" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-08-19T23:30:12Z</published>; <updated>;2023-09-07T01:17:48Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;In my reading of thermodynamics, the chemical potential <span class="math-container">;$\mu$</span>; of a system is often defined as the Gibbs free energy per unit particle (or mole, for my chemist friends) of substance. Then, for a system composed of <span class="math-container">;$N$</span>; chemical species, we have <span class="math-container">;$G = \sum_{j = 1}^N\mu_j\cdot n_j$</span>;, where <span class="math-container">;$n_j$</span>; is the number of particles of the <span class="math-container">;$j^{th}$</span>; species.</p>; <p>;Now, regarding the <span class="math-container">;$n_j$</span>;'s as the independent variables, the differential of <span class="math-container">;$G$</span>; is given by <span class="math-container">;$$ dG = \sum_{j = 1}^N \mu_j\cdot dn_j. \tag{1}$$</span>;</p>; <p>;However, if we appeal to another definition of <span class="math-container">;$G$</span>;, namely that <span class="math-container">;$G:= U + PV - TS$</span>;, and recognize that the First Law for a multi-component system takes the form <span class="math-container">;$dU = dq - dw + \sum_{j = 1}^N \mu_j \cdot dn_j$</span>;, we are at once led to the conclusion that</p>; <p>;<span class="math-container">;$$ dG = VdP - SdT + \sum_{j = 1}^N \mu_j\cdot dn_j. \tag{2}$$</span>;</p>; <p>;It <span class="math-container">;$seems$</span>; to be the case that (1) and (2) are at odds. How is it possible for both of the equations to simultaneously be true?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/q/776608</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com">;1</re:rank>; <title type="text">;When a shaken soft-drink botte is left to calm down, does it return to the same state as before being shaken?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="thermodynamics">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="pressure">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="gas">;</category>; <author>; <name>;ARGYROU MINAS</name>; <uri>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/users/363806</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/776608/when-a-shaken-soft-drink-botte-is-left-to-calm-down-does-it-return-to-the-same" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-08-18T10:36:05Z</published>; <updated>;2023-08-19T15:39:36Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;We had a disagreement with a friend:</p>; <p>;When a soft-drink (carbonated) bottle (eg, 1.5l) is shaken or dropped on the floor, if opened immediately it will spill out. However, if it is left to "calm down", then it won't spill out. Does it, however, return to the same condition as before being shaken or dropped?</p>; <p>;EDIT: To be clearer, I also want to know about the taste. Will the taste be the same before shaking and after shaking and "calming down"?</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/q/775899</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com">;3</re:rank>; <title type="text">;How fast do $\rm CO_2$ molecules transfer between air and water at equilibrium?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="equilibrium">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="diffusion">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="surface-diffusion">;</category>; <author>; <name>;Peter A</name>; <uri>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/users/273222</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/775899/how-fast-do-rm-co-2-molecules-transfer-between-air-and-water-at-equilibrium" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-08-12T21:59:31Z</published>; <updated>;2023-08-14T17:57:08Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;Suppose a bath of water is in equilibrium with the air above it at temperature T and pressure P. The concentration of <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; in the air is, say, 400ppm, and the concentration of <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; in the water is whatever is needed to be in equilibrium.</p>; <p>;Although they are in equilibrium (ie the concentrations in the air and water don't change), there will be transfer of <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; molecules between the water and the air.</p>; <p>;What is known about the rate of this transfer? Is there a formula for the half life, ie the time for half the molecules originally in the air to be in the water?</p>; <p>;Equivalently, after 10 years say, what proportion of the <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; molecules originally in the air will be in the water?</p>; <p>;<strong>;Edit</strong>; added after <a href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/users/145491/david-bailey">;David Bailey's</a>; excellent answer:</p>; <p>;My motivation is to better understand calculation of how much <span class="math-container">;$\rm CO_2$</span>; added to the atmosphere is due to industrial output and how much is from ocean de-gassing.</p>; <p>;For the purpose of this question we can assume perfect mixing in both the ocean and the air</p>; </summary>; </entry>; <entry>; <id>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/q/775813</id>; <re:rank scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com">;7</re:rank>; <title type="text">;Do particles (eg atoms/electrons) in large molecules that rotate experience pseudoforces?</stitle>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="quantum-mechanics">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="physical-chemistry">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="centrifugal-force">;</category>; <category scheme="https://physics.stackexchange.com/tags" term="coriolis-effect">;</category>; <author>; <name>;bananenheld</name>; <uri>;https://physics.stackexchange.com/users/318923</uri>; </author>; <link href="https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/775813/do-particles-eg-atoms-electrons-in-large-molecules-that-rotate-experience-ps" rel="alternate"/>; <published>;2023-08-12T07:43:34Z</published>; <updated>;2023-08-12T16:05:29Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;Imagine if you have a molecule with a large size, eg proteins. Anything that rotates experiences pseudoforces if my understanding is correct (eg coriolis, centrifugal etc).</p>; <p>;Since every molecule rotates, does this have any effect on these molecules that we could measure? Or properties that arise because of these pseudoforces? My guess would be more smeared out electron clouds, or weaker covalent bonds or something. Or a clustering of more heavy atoms in the centre point since farther from the centre would mean weaker bonds.</p>; <p>;My guess could also be that the effect is so small that it is negligble. <published>;2023-07-28T06:56:11Z</published>; <updated>;2023-07-28T07:50:39Z</updated>; <summary type="html">; <p>;Consider a simple chemical reaction, such as the association of two hydrogen atoms within the gas phase to form one hydrogen molecule.
